results.title: Torment = L' Enfer
results.creator_credit: Marin Karmitz, MK2 Productions, S A CED Productions, France 3 Cinema, Cinemanuel and Claude Chabrol
results.brief_description: This highly successful thriller from one of France’s most renowned and revered directors is set in the countryside of South western France. Hoteliers Nelly (Emmanuel Beart) and Paul (Francois Cluzet) have a marriage made in heaven. Paul is proud of his exceptionally beautiful wife, and Nelly blossoms, radiating a heady mix of innocence and sexuality that is openly admired by their male customers. However, their happiness is threatened when Paul begins to spy on his wife and becomes convinced of her infidelity. His obsessive jealousy turns to anger, which erupts in a cruel and violent climax. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Torment = Hets
results.brief_description: The storyline of this film, although simple and straightforward, reveals a beautifully observed and incise psychological drama, written by Ingmar Bergman when he was 26 years old. It is the tale of sadistic teacher in a cheerless and strict school who takes delight in exercising his reign of terror over his Latin classes. One evening as final examination time approaches, one of his students, Jan-Erik, goes to the aid of Bertha, the newsagents assistant who is drunk in the street. They become lovers, but Jan-Erik is aware of the presence of another man in her life who frightens her. He finds Bertha dead in her room and on finding the teacher in her hallway discovers he is the other man. The teacher is arrested, but is released when the cause of her death is revealed as heart failure coupled with malnutrition. Following a confrontation with the teacher in the headmasters study, Jan-Erik is expelled from school, but when the headmaster becomes aware of the teachers tyrannical methods, the boy is reinstated and the teacher punished for his crimes.

results.title: Tora! tora! tora!
results.creator_credit: Elmo Williams, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Richard Fleischer, Toshio Masuda and Kinji Fukasaku
results.brief_description: Tora! Tora! Tora! was an epic and expensive production that attempted to present realistically the battle for Pearl Harbour and the ensuing warring between the American and Japanese armies in World War II. In a unique approach, the battle is presented from both sides, rejecting traditional notions of one-sided jingoistic storytelling, typical of many war films from the 50s and 60s. For the Japanese section directors Toshio Masuda and Kinji Fukasaku pay close attention to the military manoeuvring and blunders of the campaign as well as the infighting and personal clashes within the high command. For the American section, the army is depicted as unsuspecting of an attack of this scale, hampered by limited technology and a lack of foresight. Exciting battle sequences and detailed inner-sanctum decision making within both sides of the battle make “Tora! Tora! Tora!” an interesting war movie that is not simplistic in its politics and is effective in its recreation of a historically significant event. Cast includes Martin Balsam, So Yamamura, Joseph Cotton, Tatsuya Mihashi, E.G. Marshall, James Whitemore, Takahiro Tamura, Eijiro Tono, Jason Robards.

results.title: Topsy-turvy = Topsy turvy
results.creator_credit: Simon Channing-Williams, Thin Man Films, Greenlight Fund, Newmarket Capital Group and Mike Leigh
results.brief_description: Known best for his realist depictions of contemporary working class English lives, “Topsy-turvy” finds Mike Leigh exploring the nineteenth century world of the London stage. The successful operatic team of Gilbert and Sullivan find that they have had their first flop after two decades of successful collaboration. Sullivan, the team’s composer (played by Allan Corduner), blames the stale storylines of Gilbert (Jim Broadbent). It is not until Gilbert visits an exhibition of Japanese culture that he finds inspiration again. This leads him to the creation of the story of “The Mikado”, one of the duo’s most successful productions. Though “Topsy-turvy” offers a fascinating biography of Gilbert and Sullivan - one that does not shy away from examining Sullivan’s obsession with brothels and intoxication, or Gilbert’s childlike relationship with his wife - it also offers an intriguing glimpse into the everyday lives of actors, technicians and stagehands of a previous century. The cinematography and art direction in this film are of a consistently high standard, bringing the claustrophobic, garish world of nineteenth century London vividly to life. The film won Academy Awards for make-up and for costume design. It is a musical and visual feast.

results.title: Topsoil
results.brief_description: Tells the story of one of America’s richest treasures - the thin layer of topsoil on which the people of America depend for most of their food, clothing and other necessities of life. Topsoil takes centuries to produce; it is one of nature’s most delicate and most precious gifts; yet it may be totally destroyed in a few years by improper farming methods. This film points out the difference between the topsoil and the less productive subsoil, and ends by showing how precious topsoil may be conserved while still being used for maximum production.

results.title: Tops
results.brief_description: Tops are among man’s oldest and most popular toys. This non-narrated film features 123 spinning tops from different lands. The essence of tops is captured as the stages of their movement are displayed. The second in the unfinished trilogy of toy films (ships would have been next). Music by Elmer Bernstein.

results.title: Topper
results.creator_credit: Hal Roach, RKO Radio Pictures and Norman McLeod
results.brief_description: George and Marion are killed in a car crash - but their spirits ‘live’ on, invisible, on terra firma rather than in some heavenly eternity. They discuss their predicament - and decide that they’ll have to do a good deed to go to ‘the other place’. They feel that Cosmo Topper, the bank president, should learn how to enjoy life and set about doing something about it. Some of the trouble comes from the fact that Cosmo can see them but nobody else can.

results.title: Topology
results.creator_credit: John Halas, Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films and Harold Whitaker
results.brief_description:
An animated film which illustrates those properties of geometric figures or solid bodies which remain invariant under certain transformations.
Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Topless women talk about their lives
results.creator_credit: John Swimmer Productions, New Zealand Film Commission, Fiona Copland and Harry Sinclair
results.brief_description: This fresh, low-budget, comedy of manners explores contemporary relationships through the romantic entanglements and dilemmas facing a circle of friends in their late twenties. Sinclair’s debut feature is based on a ‘micro series’ of 4 minute episodes he made for New Zealand television that followed events in the lives of a group of friends living in Auckland, and is similarly structured as a series of loosely connected episodes. Liz (Danielle Cormack) is disturbed to find that she is pregnant and potentially facing motherhood as a single mother. Her horny and geekish boyfriend (Joel Tobeck), is refusing to deal with the impending return of his other girlfriend from overseas. Prue (Willa O’Neill), Liz’s best friend, is having traumas of her own as she deals with the joys of her forthcoming marriage to Niue-born Mike (Shimpal Lelisi). Then there is the neurotic linchpin of the film, aspiring film-maker and “psychologically scarred” Ant (Ian Hughes) who experiences the trauma of attending the painfully bad premier screening of the feature film he has written. Featuring a music soundtrack by well known New Zealand acts including The Chills, The Clean, The Bats and Chris Knox, “Topless Women” effortlessly mixes comedy and drama to portray Gen-X angst.
